General course objectives:
General course objectives
The student will obtain an understanding of basic principles behind numerical simulations of microstructure evolution in crystalline materials (primarily metals) induced by chemical, mechanical and thermal external loads, including the associated changes in material properties.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Discuss the principles behind thermodynamic equilibrium calculations and kinetic diffusion simulations
Describe the principles behind the technique of linear programming
Explain the role of chance in Monte Carlo Simulations
Implement thermodynamic equilibrium calculations and diffusion simulations for solution of problems involving complex phase equilibria
Implement linear programming in crystal plasticity simulations
Implement Monte Carlo techniques to simulate grain growth and recrystallization
Relate the results of thermodynamic equilibrium calculations and diffusion simulations or linear programming to real microstructures
Assess results of Monte Carlo simulations and potential artifacts
Present different simulation methods and the obtained results orally
Content: The course is taught in three modules with each of duration of one week focused on 1) thermodynamic calculations, 2) linear programming and 3) Monte Carlo simulations. At the end of each module, the students will present the results of a small project to the teachers and the other students. The weekly projects will focus on application of the simulation methods of the module to a materials science problem. The course introduces the mentioned simulation techniques and the students will implement these to address specific problems of complex phase equilibria, deformation-induced evolution of crystallographic texture and mechanical properties, and microstructural evolution during recrystallization and grain growth. The simulations will be compared to real microstructures.
